video.title: Spring Boot Tutorial for Beginners (Java Framework)
video.description:
Learn Spring Boot in this full course for beginners. Spring Boot is an amazing framework for building Java applications. It makes it easy to create stand-alone, production-grade Spring based Applications that you can "just run".

💻 Code: https://github.com/amigoscode/spring-boot-react-fullstack

✏️ Course from Amigoscode.
🔗 Subscribe to Amigoscode YouTube channel: http://bit.ly/2HpF5V8
🔗 Full Stack Spring Boot | React | Postgres Course: http://bit.ly/2NGmUx3
🔗 Visit Amigoscode.com for more courses: http://bit.ly/2JgGW0w
🔗 Follow Amigoscode on Instagram: http://bit.ly/2TSkA9w
🔗 Join Amigoscode Closed Facebook Group: http://bit.ly/2FbuIkx

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

</dependency>

If "cannot find symbol" @NotNull , then add to pom.xml and restart (then import javax.validation... not hibernate):

<dependency> 
    <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId> 
    <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-validation</artifactId> 
</dependency>

topLevelComment.author: Veg Ahimsa
topLevelComment.text:
Postman status: 415, error: "Unsupported Media Type".
Solution: Postman Headers:
Key = "Content-Type", Value = "application/json"
(no quotes)

topLevelComment.author: Bob The Banana Builder
topLevelComment.text:
1:23:10 If you still get error "Failed to configure a DataSource: 'url'" change application.yml to:

spring:
  datasource:
    driverClassName: org.postgresql.Driver
    url: jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/demodb
    username: postgres
    password: password
    pool-size: 30

And in PostgresDatasource:
    @ConfigurationProperties("spring.datasource")

And it should work (Spring 2.4.4)

replies.author: Callum Atwal
replies.text:
DAO -> how you access data from your database/store etc

DTO -> how you transform this data to the user/output

Eg, in your DAO you might have toe fields in the DB called firstName and lastName. 
But in the output, you want to return fullName. 

In your service class, you will take the DAO and use it to then return a DTO (in this case, maybe concatenating first and last name with a space)

topLevelComment.author: Barath Vedantham
topLevelComment.text:
1:01:00 for those not getting this error and the blank name is being added, you may not have a problem with your code but actually your dependencies. IntelliJ may by default have you add Jakarta as the dependency to add @NonNull and @Valid but you actually need the "javax.validation" dependency. That's the groupId and the artifactId is "validation-api" which are to be added to your pom.xml file.

Also for those thinking this may be too fast for them, it's ok to pause the video..! and to go back and re-listen to what is being taught. These are very important concepts to learn and although they may be hard to follow along with learning them pays off.

topLevelComment.author: Diana Goncharuk
topLevelComment.text:
I had a problem at 1:19:40 where idea couldn't resolve HikariDataSource name (because i didn't have the dependency installed)
solution: add the following to your pom.xml
<dependency>
    <groupId>com.zaxxer</groupId>
    <artifactId>HikariCP</artifactId>
</dependency>

then run in the IDEA's terminal "mvn clean install"

you may also have to close and reopen IDEA to enforce the changes


Edit: I use java 8

topLevelComment.author: faruzzy
topLevelComment.text:
I think that it's worth mentioning a couple of things here.
1) @Autowired (when used with a constructor) is only required in case there is an ambiguity; meaning more than one constructor.
But there's nothing wrong with being clear that dependency is injected by Spring 
2) Instead of using @Qualifier in the constructor parameter, you can just give the name of the bean that you want to be used.
Example: 
public Person(PersonDao fakePersonDataAccessService). Notice the casing *fakePersonDataAccessService* in lieu of *FakePersonDataAccessService* or just *FakeDao* if that's how you choose to explicitly name your bean (as shown in this video).

replies.author: Jordy Ubink
replies.text:
@electrobassist Thank you very much. This also was the case IntelliJ (the same program as in this video). My Main application was in a subpackage, but didn't need to be.

So for everybody else that use ItelliJ IDEA, here are the steps:
1. Select the *package that contains* your main application, not the java file itself.
2. Hit Shift + F6 (Means: Refactor > Rename)
3. Remove the subpackage from the name and hit Refactor. In this video, the new package name should be: "com.example.demo".

And make sure that all sub packages have the correct path, see the first line of every java file:
example: "package com.example.demo.dao"

replies.author: Ben Silveston
replies.text: Don't forget that this is a crash course.  It's impossible to cover the whole of Spring Boot in under 2 hours.  If you want a more in-depth course, choose either Chad Darby's Spring and Hibernate for Beginners course or Tim Buchalka's Spring Masterclass course (both on Udemy).  Both of those instructors explain the framework under the hood and therefore explain pretty much every line of code that they write.  So I therefore highly recommend enrolling on one or both of those courses.

replies.author: Ben Silveston
replies.text:
​@Gen Prima Biocakti I'm at the same stage of the Java Masterclass course pretty much.  I personally don't have too many issues with the application in this tutorial in terms of structure and layout.  So for example how Nelson is using interfaces to communicate with the code and using important OOP concepts along the way.  Though some of the syntax is a bit confusing and at times is going over my head a bit!

I'm thinking that at least of myself, if I learnt a bit about Java Collections and Databases and even the Java Streams API to an extent, this material would make a bit more sense.  But at the same time, I don't think that you're wrong to start learning the basics of Spring from where you're at now. Just be aware though of some unexpected bumps in the road so to speak! :-)

replies.author: Sathya Govind
replies.text:
The controller, service and dao are singletons but are necessary for the autowiring in Spring to be complete. 



You're right in that the list in the AccessService isn't thread-safe but in reality when you code up an API, you'll hook it up to a real database (like Mongo) that will handle asynchronous calls to access it.
